text: My favorite music from any location in all of WoW. I'd sit in Sholazar Basin for a good 20~40 minutes on a weekly basis to listen to this, no matter which character I'd be leveling. For me, this place was a mandatory stop for every single character of mine. It also helped make farming not so boring when seeking to tame the spirit leopard on my hunter. :)

author: Goldentoon42

text: Say what you will, but WoW gave me some of my fondest memories back before I decided to quit. It's a solid game until you're burnt out on it - kinda like what happens with any other Blizzard game, actually. Yeah, some aspects of WoW seem like they'd make it a little too repetitive, but being new at the game is like stepping into a world just waiting to be completely discovered and conquered - and meanwhile, if you're lucky, your friends/family are experiencing it the same way alongside you.

author: yeawhateva21

text:
It's a shame that World of Warcraft's music is so under appreciated. I'm surprised whenever I hear people don't play the game without sound or music, when having both running at the same time can make some of the most epic battles in the game escalate to an entirely new level.

A perfect example of this is Yogg-saron. If your guild decides to check him out again, be sure you turn your sound and music on. It'll blow your mind.
author: Grey St. Onge

text: the most spiritual and moving music i have ever heard in my life, truly an epic... peaceful, calming, and defiantly a favorite by millions who play this game, by people who are fanatics of spiritual, calming music of this world... Thank you Blizzard for creating this awesomely epic music :)
author: Thallanar Rabidtooth

text: Outland actually sported quite a library of music. A lot of the music was quiet and didn't have a melody you could quite grasp, evoking Outland's desolate atmosphere, so that could be why you simply didn't notice the songs. The music played on all zones and special areas (towns, factions and other triggers). Songs also varied in zones according to time of day for areas with a day and night sky (see Nagrand) -- a sign of the game's attention to detail.
